hotspots.label: Blue Ink Cloud
hotspots.fact: When blue ink enters the clear water, it spreads out and mixes throughout the liquid. This process is called **diffusion** — that's when one substance slowly spreads and mixes evenly with another substance. Diffusion happens because tiny particles are always moving and bouncing around!

vocabulary.definition: When particles of one substance spread out and mix evenly with another substance.

hotspots.label: Clear Water Below
hotspots.fact: The clear water at the bottom of the jar shows that water is a liquid, which is one of the three main states of matter. Liquids have no fixed shape — they take the shape of their container — but they do take up space and have mass. As the ink diffuses, the water's appearance changes even though it's still the same liquid!

vocabulary.definition: Anything that takes up space and has weight; it can be a solid, liquid, or gas.

hotspots.label: Mixing Process
hotspots.fact: The swirling and spreading of the blue ink in the water demonstrates how particles move and change position. This movement happens naturally because the tiny particles that make up both the ink and water are always in motion, even when we can't see them moving. This is a physical change because the water is still water — it's just changing color as the ink mixes in!

vocabulary.definition: A change in how something looks or feels without becoming a different substance.

hotspots.label: Glass Jar Container
hotspots.fact: The glass jar holds the water and ink, showing us that containers hold liquids and keep them from spilling. Glass is a solid material with a fixed shape that doesn't change, while the water and ink inside are liquids that can flow and spread. The shape of the jar itself shows us the physical properties of solids — they keep their shape!

vocabulary.definition: A type of matter that has a fixed shape and size that doesn't change unless you break it or melt it.
